title: Libraries Stop Helping with Passports
summary: The U.S. State Department has told some public libraries to stop helping people with passport applications. These libraries have been doing this for many years, and people in their communities rely on this service. The State Department says that libraries, which are not part of the government, cannot collect fees for passports. This affects many libraries across the country, especially in states like Connecticut and Pennsylvania. Lawmakers are asking the government to let libraries continue until a new plan is made. Without this service, people might have to travel far or miss work to get a passport, which is harder for working families and rural residents. Some libraries might even have to cut jobs or close if they lose the money from passport fees.

background_read: Passports are important for traveling to other countries and proving your identity. Libraries are community places that often help with services beyond books, like passport applications. The U.S. government has rules about who can handle passports, and this article talks about how some libraries are being told to stop because they are not government-run. This affects many people who rely on libraries for easy access to passport services.
